content: I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
Bravo !

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)
dude my program stuck in 21 digits, any help?

Hi! The puzzle can actually get approved!
Hope it will become public thanks to you!

This is a clever number theory problem ‚Äî the key is noticing that divisibility by 
2
ùëõ
2
n
 forces very strict constraints on which digit goes in each position. The fact that there‚Äôs exactly one valid solution is a nice hint: you can build the number digit by digit, from least significant to most significant, by checking which choice (a or b) keeps the partial number divisible by the right power of 2 at each step. I like that it mixes modular arithmetic with constructive generation instead of brute force search.
super interesting

Hi!
As my python code succeded the last 500 digits test in less than 3 seconds, I think It's really solvable with any language so I decided to add it (the 500 digits test)!

Okay!
I have no idea why it works now but not before but its ok!
Could I borrow your code while fixing mine NicknamedTwice ?

can u check your answer for the "Still ok? 100 digits!" test?
i have:
499999944944999999499944994494499444949999444
444949494494994499449499994444944449994949944
9494994944

my code seems to work fine for all the previous tests
```py
n = int(input())
a, b = map(int, input().split())

odd  = a if a & 1 else b
even = a + b - odd

k = 0
ds = []

for i in range(1, n+1):
    d = even if (k & 1) == 0 else odd
    ds.append(str(d))
    k = (d * pow(5, i-1) + k) // 2

print(''.join(ds[::-1]))
```
i think the difficulty should be no harder than a medium (maybe even easy but not sure since i didnt spend longer than 10 minutes trying to find a solution)

I can confirm that my answer matches yours. The author's answer, however, isn't divisible by 2^100 and must be wrong.

The difficulty level could be set to Medium, as the problem is trickier (though still solvable) for players using programming languages that cannot handle arbitrarily large numbers.

Other comments:

General
* Let's modify the hint and output descriptions (see below for details) to avoid creating a false impression that there might be more than one possible answer.

Title
* The title isn't natural in English. Consider changing it to "Large Numbers with Only Two Distinct Digits".

Goal
* Please format "n", "a" and "b" as [[variables]].

* Please add ": always one in each case (try to prove it as a separate exercise)" after "such integers".

Output
* Please delete "first".

* Please remove the text starting from "Line 2:" through "so on‚Ä¶"

Constraints
* Please change "<150" to "‚â§250".

Tags
* The tag "Combinatorics" seems misleading, as it may not always be feasible to check every combination of digits.

Stub generator
* Line 2: Please change to:
read a:int b:int

* Please add a write statement, e.g. "write answer".

Thanks.
yea sure
Please update the first constraint. Thanks.
thanks!

Yes, that's why very large numbers are used for test cases!
I did'nt try it myself but I estimate that a 500 digits long number gives enough of possibillities (2^500) to prevent people to brute force the problem :)
How did you begin the puzzle? What idea(s) did you think about?

Hi! I actually don't understand Java code, could you explain me what your code does, what's the idea you using?
I know that for computing the answers, you don't really need to calculate big powers of 5, which I think you do in your code.
Also, is this BigNumber library common in Java? If it's the case then there's no problem.

Yes BigNumber is common. But Maybe it needs to be said for beginners. 

So we loop n times to choose between the odd and the even digit for each of the n digit that form the final number, from right to left.

For each loop we check if we choose the odd or the even number using "k" that is the remaining of the digit we chose and multiply by five power of 0, then 1, then 2, then 3 up to n-1 (1, 5, 25, 125, 625, 3125, 15625, 15625, etc) and this we divide by 2. 

Why 5^(i-1) and 2 ? It is because of the link between dividing by 5 and 2 for each order of 10 we go up. Maybe there is another, simplier way to find the solution but it is the one I have found. 

If I write the (still unknown) number as a sum of its decimal places:

N = d1¬∑10‚Å∞ + d2¬∑10¬π + d3¬∑10¬≤ + ‚Ä¶ + dn¬∑10‚Åø‚Åª¬π

di is the digit we are fixing at step i (i = 1 is the units place).
Because 10 = 2¬∑5, each term can be split:

di¬∑10‚Å±‚Åª¬π = di¬∑2‚Å±‚Åª¬π¬∑5‚Å±‚Åª¬π

The requirement N = 0 (mod 2^n) means that after we have fixed the first i digits, the remainder modulo 2^i must already be zero.

At the end of the loop we simply reverse the digits. 

For inputs n=500, a=9, b=2 it tooks around 3 ms
For inputs n=1000, a=9 , b=8 it tooks around 10ms
For inputs n=10000, a=2, b=3, it tooks around 453ms
For input n=100000, a=5, b=1, it tooks around 1min 53secondes

Okay, that's the same idea that I used (Idk if you can see my python solution) .
About the powers of 5, we have that '2|5^(i-1)*di' is equivalent to '2|di' .
That's because 2|5^(i-1)-1 for any integer i.
This could maybe save some time for large test cases.

I did most of what you listed above, thank you!
I'm actually trying to rework my code ('Still ok? 100 digits!' test)

Title
* After my last review, I noticed that not all answers are large numbers. Could you please remove the word "Large" from the title?

Goal
* Please format "n" (in "2^n") as a [[variable]].

Stub generator
* Line 3: Only one "write" is needed.

Cases / Solution
* To be updated.

Thanks.

About the title, the final goal of the puzzle is to find large numbers that satisfy the conditions, small numbers are only used to check the understanding of the statement, large numbers (starting at 'with more digits (21)' test) are used to check the way the code finds the answer.

Imo, "large" is an appropriate term to discribe the problem, but if you really find it has nothing to do here, no problem I'll delete it.

I understand your point, given the main challenge comes with numbers that have many digits. However, since not all answers are actually large numbers, I still feel the title should be changed to better summarise the entire puzzle.
Okay, done!
